loans.name: Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
For the last two years, Mwandawa has made a living selling firewood and clothes in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar.   She currently earns an average monthly profit of $110, and works for 12 hours a day.  

She is applying for her third loan from BRAC Tanzania and plans to use it to buy more firewood to sell. She is hoping that this loan will allow her to increase her profits, grow her business, pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.  

Mwandawa is  34 years old, married, and has three children, ages 10, 6 and 2. She also cares for two additional dependents. She will share this loan with her fellow loan group member, Jina. Jina runs a small business selling clothes and firewood in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more firewood to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Sharifa

texts.en:
For the last year and a half, Sharifa has made a living running a hardware store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to the Asaakher loan group, and currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. She works at her business for 12 hours a day.

She has applied for her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more used TVs, radios and bicycles to sell to her customers. She hopes that this loan will allow her to increase her profits, grow her business and save money for future use.  

Sharifa is 24 years old, married, and has three children. She also cares for two other dependents.

loans.use: To buy more used TVs, radios and bicycles to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina has made a living selling juice, cake and other items in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the last year. She belongs to M'MoLa group loan and currently earns an average monthly profit of $80. She works for 12 hours a day.  

Amina is applying for her first loan from BRAC Tanzania and plans to use it to buy more fruit and sugar for her business. She hopes that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business, pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.  

Amina is 38 years old, married, and has two children, ages 18 and 10.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and sugar for her business.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha has been a vegetable and firewood seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 5 years. She belongs to the Subira ina mpaka loan group (group code 2058). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $155. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood, tomatoes and vegetables for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.

Mwanaisha is 42 years old, married, and has six children: ages 24, 21, 20, 18, 16 and 14.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes, vegetables and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu has been a clothes, cosmetics and handbags seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 13 years. She belongs to Mwanzo mgumu group (group code 2026). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Each day she works at her business 12 hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes, cosmetics items and handbags for resale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.

Tatu is 31 years old, married, and has a 14-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more clothes, cosmetics items and handbags for resale

loans.name: Sada

texts.en:
Sada has been a food seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 12 years. She belongs to the Tujikomboe loan group (group code 2063). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $155. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items like rice, meat, and beans for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, pay school fees for her children, and save money for future use.

Sada is 48 years old, married, and has eight children: ages 26, 23, 21, 19, 16, 14, 12 and 11.

loans.use: To buy food like rice, beans, and meat for her business.

loans.name: Mapatano Group

texts.en:
Khadija has been a clothes and shoes seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $95. She works at her business for eight hours every day.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes and shoes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase and she will be able to pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.

Khadija is 35-years-old, married and has two children: ages 14 and 11. She also cares for two additional dependants. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Shemsa, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and shoes for business.

loans.name: Tuwe Wakweli Group

texts.en:
Asha has been a clothes seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for one year. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. Daily she works at her business 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy clothes for resale. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.

Asha is 36 years old, married, and has two children: ages 17 and 9. She also cares for two additional dependant. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Pili, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Firuza

texts.ru: Фируза молодая девушка, 22 лет, еще не замужем. Живет с родителями. После окончания школы стала  работать в местном отделении министерства образования в должности секретаря. Работа занимает большую часть времени. Кроме этой работы Фируза занимается мелким бизнесом – она продает парфюмерию. Оборот бизнеса небольшой, всего около 1000 сомони (250 долларов), но приносит хорошую прибыль, так как Фируза дает своим клиентам профессиональные советы по использованию той или иной косметики. Ее клиенты довольны и после использования ее услуг становятся ее постоянными клиентами. Фируза собирается немного расширить свой бизнес и поэтому просит займ.
texts.en:
Firuza is a young girl, 22 years old, and not yet married. She lives with her parents. After finishing school, she began working as a secretary at the local branch of the Ministry of Education, and her job takes up a lot of time. In addition, Firuza has a small business selling perfume. Her turnover is not large, approximately 1000 somoni (250 dollars), but it brings in a good profit because Firuza gives her customers professional advice on the use of one cosmetic or another. Her customers are satisfied and after availing themselves of her services become regular customers. Firuza is planning to expand her business a bit and therefore has requested a loan.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Kuzixon

texts.ru: Кузихон 59 лет, замужем и имеет 3 детей. Все дети взрослые и уже имеют свои семьи. Кузихон на пенсии, но дополнительно занимается предпринимательством. Продает детскую одежду на центральном рынке города Исфары. Кузихон ездит за товаром на оптовые рынки один раз в неделю, а затем в течении недели продает в розницу. Кузихон планирует увеличить ассортимент одежды для новорожденных, поэтому подает заявку на займ.
texts.en:
Kuzixon is 59 years old, married and the mother of three children. All her children are grown and already have their own families. Kuzixon is retired, but taken up business as a second career. She sells children's clothing at the central market in the city of Isfara. Kuzixon travels once a week to the wholesale market for goods, then over the course of the week sells them retail. She plans to increase the assortment of clothing for newborns and therefore has put in an application for a loan.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the assortment of clothing for newborns

loans.name: Abdugufron

texts.ru: Абдугуфрон занимается редким по нынешним временам делом – он изготавливает национальные сундуки. Это ремесло передалось ему от его отца, с которым он и продолжает его. Национальные сундуки у таджиков является обязательным подарком дочери, когда она выходит замуж, поэтому сундук постоянно находится в большом спросе. На постройку сундука используются доски которые высушиваются в течении 3 лет, специальная жесть для украшивания и красится с помощью краски произведенной из натуральных красителей. Сундуки Абдугуфрона прочные и красивые и поэтому не задерживаются долго. Сейчас у Абдугуфрона заканчиваются сырье и материалы и поэтому, чтобы восполнить их запас, он подает заявку на займ.
texts.en:
Abdugufron has an unusual profession for this modern age, he makes traditional chests. This trade was passed on to him from his father, and together they continue it. A Tajik chest is traditionally given to one's daughter when she marries, therefore the chests are continually in high demand. Wood that has dried for three years is needed for construction of a chest, special tin for decoration and they are painted with paints made from natural dyes. Abdugufron's chests are strong and beautiful and sell quickly. He is currently out of materials, and therefore to increase their supply, he is applying for a loan.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials

loans.name: Khader

texts.en:
Khader A. is a devoted father who is extremely dedicated to his work. He earns his living through farming; specifically, he grows apples, oranges, and strawberries. His goal is to improve his farming techniques in order to better meet the needs of his family (he has a loving wife and a 5-year-old son).

Khader is now requesting a loan in the amount of $1,000 to enable him to purchase seeds and fertilizers that will provide for an excellent harvest.

loans.use: To expand and improve his business by purchasing seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Wajiha

texts.en:
About three years ago, Wajiha S. was rather desperate and took it upon herself to start a business. In particular, she and her husband had mounting costs of living and looming expenses for their children's education (they have four school-age children). As a result, she decided to open a small grocery store, which she has seen steadily grow because of her hard work and effort.

She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $1,000 to buy more merchandise such as sweet bread, beverages, rice, pasta, vegetables, and fruit. With your help, she will be able to continue to improve her operation and to thereby satisfy her family's living expenses.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional merchandise

loans.name: Sadeq

texts.en:
Sadeq J. is a loving father of four children and a dedicated husband.  To earn a living, he operates a grocery store, where he sells vegetables, milk, and soft drinks, among other things.  Little by little, he has expanded the range of goods he offers his customers.  

Now, his micro-enterprise generates a nice stream of income which enables him to support his family.  But he needs to further increase his stock and range of merchandise (e.g., meat, flour, pasta, rice, fruit, vegetables, oil, canned foods, dairy products, bakery products, and beverages) in order to satisfy the ever-growing demands of his customers.  Accordingly, he is seeking a loan in the amount of $1,000.  With your help, Sadeq will be able to continue to take good care of his family.

loans.use: To satisfy customer demand by purchasing additional merchandise

loans.name: Fwaz

texts.en: Fwaz A. E. is a young man who lives with his mother and his four sisters. He owns a grocery store and wants his store to do well. Being the only income earner in his household, he wants to provide his family with the best life possible. He is requesting a loan with which he will increase his volume of merchandise so as to provide his customers with a wider diversity of products.

loans.use: Increase merchandise to provide a diversity of products.

loans.name: Epefania

texts.en:
Mrs. Epefania C. lives in Sto.Nino, Pagadian City, Zamboanga del Sur. She is married and has three children.  Her husband is a laborer who supports the family tirelessly. Epefania applied for her membership to Paglaum MPC when she learned of its loan opportunities. Upon hearing all the benefits of being a member of this Kiva field partner, she didn't hesitate.  She maintains herself as a credible member in good standing, and she always pays her loans in a timely manner. 

Recently, she asked for a loan of $225 for additional capital for her variety store business. Through this project, she believes that she can earn more income and be of greater help to her family.  Epefania has found comfort in being able to provide for their financial needs through Paglaum MPC, and she is deeply thankful.

loans.use: to buy additional inventory

loans.name: Murodchon

texts.ru: Муродчон занимается куплей продажей сухофруктов на местных рынках. Ему 38 лет, женат, имеет 2 детей. Основная его работа оплачивается низко и поэтому бизнес хорошее дополнение к его заработной плате. В МикроИнвест пришел недавно и изучив его условия Муродчон решил получить небольшой займ для расширения своего бизнеса.
texts.en:
Murodchon is in the business of selling dry fruits on the local markets. He is 38 years old, married and has two children. His main job does not pay very much and this is why his business is a good addition to his salary. He has come to MicroInvest just recently and after learning the terms Murodchon has decided to get a small loan to expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Shohusein

texts.ru: Шохусейн занимается ремонтом бытовой техники, а точнее холодильного оборудования. Шохусейну 31 год, женат, 3 детей. Недавно он открыл свою собственную мастерскую. Где он спокойно может принимать своих клиентов. Кроме того, что его клиенты привозят холодильники к нему в мастерскую он еще выезжает к ним на своей машине. Запасные части для холодильников различных марок, а также фреон он покупает самостоятельно и затем после установки получает с клиентов вознаграждение, которое и является его прибылью. Для покупки запчастей ему и необходим займ.
texts.en:
Shohusein is in the business of repair of household appliances, mostly refrigerators. Shohusein is 31 years old, married and has three children. He has opened his own repair shop just recently where he can meet and service his clients. Besides that his customers bring their refrigerators to his shop he also travels out to them on his car. He buys the spare parts for different refrigerator brands and freon himself and then gets a reimbursement after installation which is his profit. He needs a loan to buy the spare parts.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Hikmat

texts.ru: Хотя Хикмат 61 год, она на пенсии, но все еще занимается бизнесом. Она продает ткани на местных рынках. Ей помогает ее муж, который тоже на пенсии. Она воспитала 5 детей. Старшие дети иногда по воскресным дням помогают матери торговать. Хикмат закупает ткани оптом на оптовом рынке. А раз в месяц выезжает на оптовый рынок который находится в соседнем Кыргызстане, куда надо ехать в течении нескольких часов на машине. Хикмат имеет хороший оборотный капитал, но для закупки весеннего ассортимента тканей решила подать заявку на КИВА.
texts.en:
Even that Hikmat is 61 years old and is retired she is still running her business. She sells fabrics on the local markets. Her husband helps her and he is also retired. She has raised five children. Sometimes her older children help her with the business on Sundays. Hikmat buys the fabrics in wholesale on the wholesale markets. She goes to the wholesale market once a month which is located in the neighboring Kyrgyztan which takes several hours to get to by car. Hikmat has a good working capital and to buy a spring assortment of fabrics she has decided to apply for a loan at Kiva.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a spring assortment of fabrics

loans.name: Rec Waterloo Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the R.E.C Primary School, Waterloo. R.E.C. Primary School Waterloo was founded in 1926 by the government. R.E.C Waterloo has a total number of 546 pupils and a total number of fourteen staff. Since 2006, when Nafisatu A. T. took over the administration of the school, R.E.C Primary School Waterloo has been producing good results at the National Primary School Exams (NPSE). However, like many schools in Sierra Leone, REC Waterloo lacks adequate classrooms, seating accommodations and adequate learning and teaching materials. This will be the first loan for teachers of the R.E.C Primary School from SMT/Kiva. Government salaries are usually quite small for teachers, thus making teaching an unattractive profession for many whose primary motivator is money. Many choose other jobs over teaching because of the small salary, thus starving the field of qualified personnel to teach the children. The few who remain in the classrooms have to find other ways of making ends meet. The vast majority of them engage in either businesses or agriculture or they provide extra tutorial classes for the children (although this is a practice the government is trying to stop).

Needless to say, loans from SMT are a great help to the teachers in order to boost their businesses or investing it in something productive. Many want to go to school but could not afford the cost. Some will want to buy pieces of furniture, but their monthly salary is not enough to let them do so. With a loan, they will be able to meet some of these needs. And with their monthly salaries, they can repay easily via a payroll deduction type of system. Nafisatu A. T. (left) is the head teacher of R.E.C Primary School Waterloo. She was born in Matotoka village, Tonkolili district, northern Sierra Leone. She is fifty-four years of age and married with four children. One is already an adult and three are still attending schools. She has been a teacher for thirty-six years now. Nafisatu will use this loan to buy bundles of corrugated iron zinc to roof her house. She does not expect to complete the roofing of her house with this loan, but with subsequent loans, however, she will certainly complete the roofing of her house. This will bring happiness and joy to Nafisatu as it will relieve her of the burden of paying exorbitant rents.

loans.use: To buy corrugated iron zinc for house roof

loans.name: Odontuya

texts.en:
Odontuya S. is 39, married and has one daughter. Her family lives in a "ger" (a nomadic Mongolian tent) district in Henti, the Mongolian province of Chinggis (Genghis) Khan's birthplace. 

Her husband, Erdenebayar, is a taxi driver. Her only daughter, DolgorS., is a 19-year-old university student. Since 2003, Odontuya has been running a clothing retail business at the local market. She goes to Ereen, a Chinese border city where many Mongolians buy cheap goods for their businesses, a few times a year. 

When she first started her business, her working capital was around 500,000 MNT. From profits, she has bought a house and a car for her husband's taxi service. As a result of her hard work, Odontuya's business inventory has increased to 1,200,000 MNT. 

Odontuya is a loyal and hard-working person. She is one of many repeat XacBank borrowers. With this loan, she will buy adult clothing apparel from Ereen, China.

loans.use: To buy adult clothing apparel from Ereen, China.

loans.name: Sun's Group

texts.en:
This is a small loan for three women who live in Battambang Province, Cambodia. 

Mrs. Sun S., age 30, has been selected to be group leader by the other members. She is a widowed mother who has two children who are still young and enrolled in school. Her mother, also a widow, lives with her and helps support the family by selling a kind of Khmer sweet. 

S. currently earns an income by selling different kinds of fruits in the local market. She has operated her business for a year. She usually buys her produce from a wholesale supplier and the farmers in bulk and sells them at retail to gain income. S. would like a loan to accrue stock of fruit to sell. 

The other two borrowers are:

C., who sells fish in the market and requests a loan to buy more fish for sale.

V., a vegetable seller seeking a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To accrue stock of fruit to sell

loans.name: Batsayhan

texts.en:
Batsayhan B. is 42, married and the father of two. His family lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His spouse, Sarantsetseg, is unemployed and stays at home. Batsayhan's eldest daughter is a university student, and his youngest attends elementary school. 

In 2005, Batsayhan started his retail business along with a taxi service. When he began his business, he had only one vehicle and drove it himself. From his profit, he has been able to buy two more cars, which he rents out to other taxi drivers. 

His daily income per car is around 12,000 tugrug ($1.00 USD=1450 MNT), and his monthly income can reach over 1 million tugrug. With this loan, he will buy a refrigerator for his home. Batsayhan is a hard-working person who wishes a happy life for his two daughters.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Otgontsetseg

texts.en:
Otgontsetseg G. is 40, married and has one daughter. Her family lives in a "ger" (a nomadic Mongolian tent) district in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family proudly owns the plot of land where they live. 

In 2001, she started a shoe business at Narantuul, the largest year-round outdoor market. Her business was a success, but the brutally cold Mongolian winter caused her to have health complications. Eventually she was forced to close her shoe stall at Narantuul and buy a clothing stall at Hantalst, an indoor market. 

Otgontsetseg goes to Ereen, a Chinese border city where many Mongolians buy cheap goods to resell, once a month to buy fashionable women's shoes. Her husband works as a taxi driver, and her only daughter is a university student. 

She is requesting a loan to buy shoes for the spring and summer, which are usually very busy. Otgontsetseg says, "Selling cheap shoes is not great for the customer. Consumers like cheap goods, but they also want quality. I will try to sell inexpensive but high-quality shoes in the future."

loans.use: To buy shoes for the spring and summer

loans.name: Keo's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. S. is a borrower in a group with three other borrowers. S., 60, has been selected to be the leader by the members. 

Currently, she is buying and selling used goods out of her home. S. is a divorced mother of one child — a married daughter who still lives in the family home. She also helps her mother selling used goods, while her husband is a vehicle repairer. 

S. needs a loan to upgrade her profitable investment.

The other three borrowers are:

V. sells dessert from her home and she asks for a loan to buy a motorbike for family riding.

P. is a dessert seller seeking a loan to purchase construction materials for her husband's business.

S. sells groceries and requests a loan to increase the quantity of her grocery inventory.

The borrowers are people living in Ratanak Commune, in Battambang Province.

loans.use: To invest in selling more used goods

loans.name: El

texts.en:
El M. was born in 1970 and has been living in Phnom Penh City for years. She presently works as a garment worker in the garment factory, which is located near her house. She usually works for eight hours per day with a specific salary of $80 a month to manage her family's living expenses and especially to make sure her three children, who are students, receive the highest educations. 

Her husband helps support the family by fishing in and around the public lakes. The family's living conditions are not comfortable because their house has some broken parts and the polluted environment. Therefore, M. has requested a loan to repair her house and proposes to use the remainder of the loan to buy a boat for her husband's fishing.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en:
A small-size wooden house and a store located in Phnom Penh belong to Mrs. C. and two other family members.

To earn a living, C. runs a small business by selling breakfast foods to the neighbors. She can earn approximately $3 each day. For another source of income, her husband drives a trailer-motor taxi. 

C.'s husband is facing difficulty in his business activities, because the motorbike needs frequent repairs. Thus, C. is applying for a loan for her husband to purchase a trailer motorcycle to replace the old one. The loan will help them attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer motorcycle

loans.name: Srun

texts.en:
Srun L. is 28 years old and a resident of Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, where she has been running a business as a Khmer cake seller for three years. Her business is now going well, and she has a lot of regular customers come to buy her product, because she is skilled in communication in the village. 

As the another source of daily income, her husband works as a truck repairer. He earns around $5 a day. The couple lives with one child, who is minor and enrolled in school. The family has been building its house for a long time, but the house is lacking the spare parts needed. 

Right now, L. needs a loan to purchase more wood and furniture to decorate her house.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and furniture to decorate her house

loans.name: Silaulelei

texts.en:
Silaulelei T., 75, is a widow with six children.  She has many years of experience in the pig farm business. Her loan will be used to buy cement, wires, timber, nails and iron roofing for building a proper shelter for her pig business. 

She sells six days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 166 Tala (about US$82).  SPBD loans are Silaulelei’s only access to capital, because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used only on the business.

loans.use: To purchase timber, nails, iron roofing and more pigs

loans.name: Altansuh

texts.en:
Altansuh T. is 27, married, and the father a 3-year-old son who is attending kindergarten. Altansuh's family lives in a "ger" (a nomadic Mongolian tent) district in Arhanghay, one of Mongolia's central provinces.

Altansuh and his wife started a retail business last year that imports wooden planks from Ereen, a border city in China where many Mongolians buy goods to resell. He has many repeat clients who are mostly carpenters or people who want to build a wood yard at their home. During the last year, Altansuh's business capital increased from 2500,000 tugrugs to 3000,000 tugrugs ($1.00 =1450 MNT).

He and his wife are planning to build their own wood-working shop. With this loan, Altansuh will go to Ereen, China, to buy more wood.

loans.use: To buy wood

loans.name: Altantuya

texts.en:
Altantuya G. is 23 and married. She lives in a "ger" (a nomadic Mongolian tent) district in Arhanghay, one of the Mongolian central provinces. 

Together with her husband, Hangarid, she has been running an office supply and service center.  Some of the services she offers are taking photos, scanning, printing and copying documents. 

Both Altantuya and Hangarid graduated from the Mongolian University of Science and Technology with degrees in computer science. Altantuya had only one desktop computer when she started her business. With the profit, she has bought more equipment, such as a printing machine, scanner, copy machine and two computers. 

She requests a loan to buy more office supplies to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To buy more office supplies

loans.name: Amarsayhan

texts.en:
Amarsayhan D. is 37, married and the mother of two. Her family lives in Arhanghay, one of the Mongolian central provinces. Both her sons go to an elementary school. 

In 1999, together with her husband, Lhagvasuren, she started a clothing business at the local market. Her husband goes to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, once or twice every month to buy used clothes imported from South Korea. Altantuya resells the clothes for a cheap price from her clothing stall. 

Her dream is to expand her business by opening another stall. With this loan, Altantuya will buy more used clothes.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes.

loans.name: Mona

texts.en:
Mona P., 26, is married with two children.  She has one year of experience in the pancake and pork buns business. She sells to the general public seven days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (about US$104).  SPBD loans are Mona’s only access to capital, because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used only on her business.

loans.use: Purchase flour, oil, sugar, onions, salt and yeast

loans.name: Bin

texts.en:
The picture is Mrs. Bin R., 40, who lives in Phnom Penh City and is the mother of five children who are single. One of her sons works as a local building worker. 

To make a daily income, she usually buys raw ingredients from the local market to make cakes and sells them to the villagers who live near her house. Beside this, she always has cultivated rice for income. She is married to Mr. Sokhon, age 41, who makes a a living by fishing, and who works with her in the farming business. 

The mature rice season is approaching, The family is lacking the money to hire a harvester to harvest their rice crop. Therefore, R. has decided to ask for US$400 to be able to make that possible.

loans.use: To hire a harvester to harvest their rice crop

loans.name: Dagiisuren

texts.en:
Dagiisuren A. lives with her husband and two teenage daughters in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her two children are high school students and her husband drives a passenger bus between cities. 

Dagiisuren has a small drug store in the Chingeltei district. She started the drug store in 2000, and her business has been a success from the start. From her profit, she has been able to rent a stall in a local apparel retail market that she runs in addition to her drug store. 

With these two businesses, her business capital has reached to 3,000,000 MNT ($1 USD=1,450 MNT). As her businesses do well, she needs more capital to expand. She requests a loan to buy more drugs and clothing for her shops. 

Dagiisuren is a hard-working woman with many dreams. She hopes that her daughters will receive good educations and pursue the careers that they choose.

loans.use: To buy more drugs

loans.name: Loluama

texts.en: Loluama L., 55, is married with six children. She has three years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the villagers seven days a week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (~62 USD). SPBD loans are Loluama’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to buy raw materials needed to upgrade her business.

loans.use: Purchase sugar, flour, yeast, oil, kerosene cooker and frying pan

loans.name: Noumea

texts.en: Noumea A., 42, is married with five children. She has five years of experience in the vegetable garden business. She sells to the general public seven days a week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD). SPBD loans are Noumea’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to buy raw materials needed to upgrade her business.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of fertilizers and vegetable seeds for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Dolgor

texts.en:
Dolgor J. lives with her husband and one of her two children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her youngest son is a high school student, and her oldest son is married and lives with his own family. Dolgor is a trained seamstress. For the past few years, she has been sewing various parts of gers, a traditional Mongolian yurt (circular tent) that is built with a wooden frame and cloth cover and is used for insulation. A significant percent of Mongolian families still live in gers. 

Dolgor sews different woolen ropes and covers for gers. The demand for ropes and ger covers increases sharply during the summers, which is the main tourist season. Many tourist camps build new gers for their foreign guests. Dolgar has a contract with a local tourist camp to provide the necessary ropes and covers for all of their gers. She requests a loan to purchase wool and cotton for sewing.

loans.use: To purchase wool and cotton for sewing

loans.name: Faasavali

texts.en:
Faasavali T., 45, is married with 3 children. She has many years of experience in the vegetable garden and the shop business. She sells to the general public 7 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD, Kiva's partner. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).

SPBD loans are Faasavali’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used on her businesses only.

loans.use: Purchase wheelbarrow, seeds, fertilizer, snack foods, tinned foods and frozen foods

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
Merly S. is a 58-year-old mother of seven. Her husband Arnaldo is a fisherman. She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), Kiva's partner, to get capital four years ago. She is weaving mats and bags made of pandan leaves and raises pigs for fattening to help support the family.

She applied for this loan to buy assorted foods for her variety "sari-sari" store she had just started from the sales of her pigs. She wants to engage in this business in order to have a regular income since mats and bags are sold in seasons. However, she wants to invest some of her loan to buy raw materials for her weaving in order to sustain its order.

She hopes that in the future, she can save enough money to support a grocery store and buy raw materials in bulk to get a lesser price in the market. She dreams of sending her children in college.

loans.use: To buy assorted foods for variety store and to buy raw materials for weaving.

loans.name: Tseelham

texts.en:
Tseelham J. lives with her husband and three children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. All three of her children are high school students.

Tseelham has a small sewing shop. In 2004, she rented a small working space in the basement floor of an apartment building in the city. In Mongolia, it is common for apartment owners to rent out basement space for commercial use and it is usually the cheapest working space available. She sewed various clothes for children, using a manual sewing machine. After lots of hard work she has expanded the business by purchasing two automatic sewing machines. Her business capital has increased from 150,000 MNT ($1 USD=1500 MNT) to 1,800,000 MNT.

She requests a loan to purchase more raw materials for sewing traditional costumes. In April and May, there will be graduation ceremonies for colleges and universities. In Mongolia, it is a tradition for girls to wear traditional costumes during their graduation ceremonies, which causes demand for traditional costumes to spike. In the future, she would like to have her own work space, from which she could run her business more efficiently and comfortably.

loans.use: To purchase more raw materials for sewing traditional costumes.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina M., 34, is married with 5 children. She has many years of experience in the ice cake and popcorn business. She sells to the villagers 7 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD, Kiva's partner. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).

SPBD loans are Christina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase sugar, corn, oil, cordial, foam cups

loans.name: Bathangay

texts.en:
S. Bathangay is 34, married and the father of a two-year-old daughter. Batghangay's family lives in Arhanghay, one of Mongolia's central provinces.

In 2004, he participated in a cobbler training program at the center of his province. Since then, together with his spouse Munhtuya, he has been running a shoe repair shop. In 2007, with their profit, they bought a shop and moved to a new home close by. S. has many repeat customers partly due to his humble personality.

Bathangay's family lives in a "ger" (traditional Mongolian housing tent) district on rental land. Soon he and his wife would like to own a plot of land. With this loan, Bathangay will buy shoe repair supplies.

loans.use: To buy shoe repair supplies.

loans.name: Mukaddas

texts.ru: Мукаддас - молодая женщина 27 лет, эамужем, имеет 2 детей. Муж работает пастухом. Она откармливает крупно-рогатый скот дома, а муж пасет мелко-рогатый  скот в горах. После 2-3 месяцев откармливания, они продают скот на базаре. Этим они зарабатывают на жизнь. Мукаддас хочет купить еще одну дойную корову, чтобы и откармливать и доить молоко для своих детей.
texts.en:
Mukaddas is a young woman of 27 years old, married and has two children. Her husband works as a shepherd. She raises cattle at home and her husband shepherds smaller cattle in the mountains. After two to three months of feeding they resell the cattle on the market. This is how they earn their living. Mukaddas wants to buy one more milk cow to feed it and have milk from it for her children.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For raising and reselling of cattle

loans.name: Repeka

texts.en:
Repeka K., 21, is single with no children. She has zero years of experience in the pork buns business. She sells to the general public 3 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD, Kiva's partner. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (~62 USD).

SPBD loans are Repeka’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan on the business.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of flour, yeast, baking powder, sugar and mutton flaps

loans.name: Bulgamaa

texts.en:
Bulgamaa J. is 41, married and the mother of two. Her husband Batdorj stays at home and drinks.

In 1991, Bulgamaa started her dairy sales business at the local market. She buys dairy products such as aaruul (dried milk) and airag (fermented horse milk) from wholesalers. When she began her business, her working capital was 100,000 tugrugs a month. Her family used to live in a "ger" (nomadic Mongolian tent) district on rented land. With her profit, she was able to buy the land they live on.

Now she is working hard to expand her dairy business by renting another stall. Her working capital has increased to 1,000,000 ($1.00 USD=1450 MNT). She requests a loan to buy more dairy products to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To buy more dairy products

loans.name: Faaliliu

texts.en:
Faaliliu V., 41, is married with 6 children. She has many years of experience in the shop business. She sells to the general public 5 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD, Kiva's partner. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).

SPBD loans are Faaliliu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to buy more goods for the shop.

loans.use: Purchase frozen foods, snacks, beverages, tin foods, sugar, flour, salt, rice, onions, diapers, toilet paper, soap

loans.name: Davaadolgor

texts.en:
Davaadolgor D. is a 39-year-old married woman. Her family lives in Arhanghay, one of Mongolia's central provinces.

In 1999, together with her husband Sunduijav, Davaadolgor started her retail sales business at the local market. Once every month, her husband goes to Ereen, a Chinese border city, to buy cosmetics and housing supplies such as napkins, toothpaste and toothbrushes.

As a result of ten years of hard work, her business capital has increased from 800,000 tugrugs to 2,500,000 tugrugs ($1.00 USD=1450 MNT). With her profit she has bought the stall that she had rented for many years. She requests a loan to buy kids' apparel and cosmetic goods.

loans.use: to buy kids' apparel and cosmetic goods.

loans.name: Eka

texts.en:
Eka S., 45, is married with four children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public five days per week.

This is her first loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (about $83). SPBD loans are Eka’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, weed killer, knives, fertilizer and a wheelbarrow

loans.name: Nikolao

texts.en: Nikolao S., 50 and single with no children, has many years of experience in the sewing business, selling to the general public six days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD, and expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala ($145).  SPBD loans are Nikolao’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase a second-hand sewing machine, rolls of materials, and sewing equipment and tools.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok I., age 42, sells fresh fishes in the busy market. As another source of income, she is buying and selling used goods out of her home. In both businesses, she can generate $4 per day to support her family's food requirements.

She has been married for years wI. four children who are single. One of her sons is learning a skill as a motorbike repairman and he will invest his knowledge to earn money. Mrs. I.'s husband works as a supervisor of military policemen.

The family also needs to pay for a taxi to get to work and when they want to go somewhere. They hope to reduce the cost of transportation. Thus, I. is requesting a loan to purchase a used motor for the family's requirements.

loans.use: To purchase a used motor for the family's requirements

loans.name: Georgia

texts.en:
Mrs. Georgia F. is a 43-year-old mother of eight. Her husband Leonardo is a baker. She does body massage to help support the family. Her irregular income plus her husband's limited income from baking is not enough to provide all the basic needs of their eight children. She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.) to get capital to start a new venture, a livestock fattening project. 

Georgia applied for this loan to buy one cow and one pig for fattening to continue her business. She is very fortunate to have this opportunity for getting bigger capital. She hopes that in the future she will be able to send her sons and daughters in school to get a degree for them to land a good job.

loans.use: To buy one cow and one pig for fattening

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sayadjan Aqa Group

texts.en:
This is the Sayadjan Aqa group. There are two members in this group. They live in district 10 of Kabul, Afghanistan. And each of them would like to take out a loan for their own business.

Marwa wants to take out a loan for carpet weaving; she wants to buy necessary materials for her business. Also Fowzya wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of selling fuel and wants to buy necessary materials for his business.

They are very happy with this process of small loans in Afghanistan and they want to thank Kiva and AFSG in Afghanistan.

loans.use: to expand and enlarge their businesses

loans.name: Mahboba Group

texts.en:
Mahboba is the group leader of mahboba group. There are four members in this group. They want to expand their businesses and make them larger.

Mahboba wants take out a loan for her business selling cosmetics. Zaheda wants to take a loan for her son’s business of photography. Farkhanda wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of general store. Also Zahra wants to take a loan for her business of tailoring. They have requested a group loan of 30000 Af.

They are all thankful to Kiva lenders for their great support.

loans.use: to enlarge their businesses

loans.name: Izzatbibi

texts.ru: Иззатбиби - женщина 48 лет, замужем, имеет 3-х детей. Занимается оптово-розничной продажей кондитерских изделий на рынке Фаровон г. Гафурова. Муж временно не работает. Ей помогают сыновья. За все время кредитования, она целенаправленно использует свой займ, и расширяет свой бизнес. Для того чтобы женить своих сыновей, она должна расширять свой бизнес, для получения большей прибыли. Иззатбиби очень довольна нашим кредитованием, и желает еще большего процветания.
texts.en:
Izzatbibi is 48 years old, married and has three children. She is in a wholesale-retail business of selling confectioneries on the market Farovon in the town of Gafurov. Her husband is not working temporarily and her sons are helping her. During all the time of lending she purposefully used the loan to expand her business. To be able to get her sons married she has to expand the business to get good profits. Izzatbibi is very satisfied with the loans and wishes to be even more successful.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For wholesale and retail of confectioneries

loans.name: Nury

texts.en:
M. Nury lives in Khujand with her big family. She is married with 3 children. Nury is engaged in commercial services, trading in children's wear that she brings from Istaravshan. Nury has good taste so she brings a good assortment.

Nury has been selling children's wear for 4 years. She has applied to Kiva for a business development loan of 1500 STJ for 6 months to import a seasonal assortment. Nury thanks Kiva for its support.

loans.use: Import seasonal children's wear

loans.name: Muborak

texts.ru: Муборак Ахмедова - женщина 41 лет. Замужем, имеет 4-х детей. Занимается продажей детской одежды на рынке Фаровон. Закупает товар из рынка г. Истаравшан. За 1 год кредитования она хоть и немного, но расширила свой бизнес. Этот и последующие займы она хочет использовать для расширения своего бизнеса и улучшить свой уровень жизни. Она благодарит все микро-финансовые организации за то что они дают возможность людям повысить свой уровень жизни.
texts.en:
Muborak A. is 41 years old. She is married and has four children. She sells children's clothing on the Favoron market. She buys the merchandise on the market of the town of Istaravshan. During the one year of lending she has expanded her business even just a little bit. She wants to use this loan and future loans to expand her business and improve her living standards. She is very grateful to all of the micro finance organizations for giving people an opportunity to improve their living conditions.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Bizainab

texts.en:
T. Bizainab first applied to MicroInvest in 2004, and she is an active client who trusts our loan program and expects a long-term cooperative relationship. Bizainab lives in Khujand and she is married with 2 children. She trades in the local bazaar in children's wear that she brings from Istaravshan and Uzbekistan. She has a good assortment and repeat customers. 

Bizainab has applied for a Kiva business loan of 1000 TJS for 3 months to import seasonal wear. The increase in business turnover will permit her to widen her trade area and her assortment of clothes in the future for a mini-market opening.

loans.use: To import seasonal wear

loans.name: Vy

texts.en: Vy H., 39, has been selling fresh fishes to her neighbors in her village for years. She sells the fish that she gets from her husband's fishing and that she buys from the wholesale suppliers as well. Beside her business, she is also a good homemaker who cooks delicious food and cares for her four children, who are single and still live in the family home. To help feed the family a little more, one of her sons is a worker for a garment industry, whilst her husband is a local fisherman. Because her husband's fishing is a profitable investment for the family, Vy H. is looking for a loan in order to buy more tools for her husband's fishing business.

loans.use: To buy more tools for fishing business

loans.name: Mohamd

texts.en:
Mohamd A. is 38 years old and married. He lives with his wife and his six children in Gaza City in Palestine. Mohamd devotes his time to selling prepared meals in the streets from a traveling cart.

Mohamd is requesting a loan of US $1000 to purchase raw ingredients for making food. Mohamd dreams of being finished with selling in the street and of having his own restaurant and a place of his own.

loans.use: Purchase raw ingredients for making food

loans.name: Muminahon

texts.en:
K. Muminahon is 36 years old and married with 2 children. She lives in Khujand and is engaged in selling small wares. It is street trading, and she trades in chewing gum, cigarettes, and packages. Muminahon is a school teacher by profession but she does not work as a teacher because of the low salary. 

Muminahon dreams of eventually opening a serious business, such as a restaurant with national cooking. She is ready to work hard to realize her dream. So, Muminahon has applied for a Kiva business development loan of 2500 STJ to start a business selling flour. Her brother brings the flour from Kyrgyzstan and she intends to sell the flour but needs to open a trade outlet.

loans.use: To start a business selling flour

loans.name: Shire Banow Group

texts.en:
Shire Banow is the group leader of the Shire Banow group. There are four members in this group. The group members want to take out  a loan of 58,800 Af; each of the group members wants the loan for her business' progress.

Pary Jan wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of leather sewing; they want to buy necessary materials for his business. Habiba wants to take out a loan for her husband’s business of  leather box sewing. And Shire Banow wants to take out a loan for her son’s business selling car parts. And Nadya wants to take a loan for her business of quilting. They all want to expand their businesses and have them progress.  They all would like to expand their businesses through the loan.   

They want to support their families and make a better future for them.

loans.use: buying necessary materials for their businesses

loans.name: Chhay

texts.en:
Chhay O., 53, is a humble villager living in Phnom Penh. A widowed mother, she cares for her five children, who are single and attend school. To support the family's daily living, she sells a variety of groceries out of her home, and also plants vegetables O. her farmland to sell. All of her children help her businesses when they are not studying.

Chhay O.'s investments are running smoothly and provide her with an income of $5 per day. Because her businesses are growing, she hopes to increase her income by taking out a a loan to use as extra capital to invest in her businesses.

loans.use: To invest in her grocery and farming businesses

loans.name: Khidoyat

texts.en:
K. Khidoyat first applied for a business-development loan with Kiva's partner MicroInvest in 2007. Thanks to previous loans, she could improve business terms and stabilize her business of making and selling the national bread in hard market-competition conditions.

Khidoyat has made the national bread known as “lepeshky” for 10 years. She has one trade outlet for selling the national bread but wants to open one more trade outlet in the local crowded bazaar, “Panjshanbe,” to increase sales and turnover of her national bread.

Khidoyat is applying to Kiva for the business-support loan of 3,200 STJ for eight months. She thanks Kiva for the small-business development and wishes all the best.

loans.use: To open one more trade outlet in “Panjshanbe,” the local crowded bazaar

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en:
Mrs. S., 24, is a garment worker in the garment industry. Her husband Seng, 23, is a domestic building worker. The young couple live with their one young child, who is enrolled in school.

Because the family's house is too old and small for them, they both have decided to look for a loan to repair their old house. The family lives in Phnom Penh, while they are pictured here.

loans.use: To repair their old house

loans.name: Savan

texts.en:
Mrs. Savan S. (in the picture with her daughter), 46, is a widow with two daughters. One of her daughters is married and lives outside the family home and another one is assisting her with the vegetable-selling business. Savan also has an old mother who is living with her. The family lives along national road number one about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Savan has been selling vegetables for 21 years. She buys them from the villagers for resale at a market in Phnom Penh. She has only one shop for selling vegetables. She hopes to expand her business to become bigger and bigger, therefore she is asking for her first loan of $1,200 to purchase one more shop for her daughter and to purchase vegetables on contract for resale.

loans.use: To purchase one shop for selling vegetables

loans.name: Savang

texts.en:
Mrs. Savang S., 41, and her husband, Mr. Him Em, 40, who live along National Road Number One about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, were married in 1990 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. One daughter is assisting her mother in selling vegetables and the other three children are in school.

Savang has been selling vegetables for 21 years, buying them locally for resale at the market in Phnom Penh while her husband, a farmer, grows rice and cucumbers. She is now requesting her first loan of $1,000 to expand her business to better help support the family.

loans.use: To expand her selling vegetables business.

loans.name: Savorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Savorn V., 32, and her husband, Mr. Eat Mao, 32, were married in 1998 and have two children: one son and one daughter. Their daughter is in school. The family lives along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Savorn has been a garment factory worker for two years while her husband has been driving a motor taxi for five years. Because the family lacks a proper restroom, she is asking for a loan of $400 to build one.

loans.use: To build a restroom for family use.

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Mr. Rin S., 29, and his wife, Mrs. Hoeun Nhoek, 26, were married in 1999 and have two children: one son who is still young and one daughter who is in school. The family lives on Long National Road Number One, about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Rin has been driving a motor taxi for ten years. Mrs. Hoeu Nhoek has been selling fish for twelve years; it is a skill she learned from her mother. She buys fish from Prek Pnao market for resale at Koki market.

Rin is asking for his second loan of $1,000 to level the land around his house and to buy more fish for his wife to sell.

loans.use: To level the land around his house and to buy more fish for his wife to sell

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna R., 38, and her husband, Mr. Sokha Poin, 43, who live in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, were married in 1985 and have four children: one son and three daughters. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home, one daughter is a garment factory worker and another one attends school. Her husband is blind.

Vanna has been selling porridge and groceries for six years. Vanna’s motorbike broke down so she is asking for her first loan of $250 to make repairs and to purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To repair her motorbike and purchase grocery items for resale

loans.name: Mach

texts.en:
Mrs. Mach P., 49, and her husband, Mr. Phy Chea, 44, have been married for twenty-five years and have six children: five sons and one daughter. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home, one son is an elevator technician, and the other four children attend school. Besides her children, she also has her mother and one sister living with her. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Mach has been a silk weaver for one year. In addition to weaving, she has been hired by her villagers to spin silk so she can earn extra income to support her family. Her husband has been a wooden house builder for twenty-eight years. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a table saw for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchase a table saw.

loans.name: Phum

texts.en: Phum M. is 44 years old and generates a daily income of $5 per day by selling fish. She is married to Yan who is 32 years old and owns a trailer-motorbike taxi service. He also earns approximately $5 each day to manage the family's expenses. They have four children who go to the local public school. The family's income is decreasing because Yan's motorbike often breaks down. Because of this, he can't attract as many customers as before. To solve the problem, M. has decided to take a loan for her husband to buy a new trailer-motor to replace the existing one.

loans.use: To buy a trailer-motor to replace an existing one

loans.name: Oibuvi

texts.en: K. Oibuvi lives in Taboshar, Tajikistan. She is married and has six children. As with many rural residents, Oibuvi is engaged in the livestock business. She makes and sells soured milk products. Oibuvi has been in the livestock business for 15 years. Her decision to start this business came from the experience of helping her mother to take care of home animals. Oibuvi applies to KIVA with a request for a business development loan of 2,000 TJS (~US$ 525) for 8 months, so that she can purchase milk-making equipment. She thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To purchase milk-making equipment

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en:
Visitacion D. G. is a 63-year-old mother of two. Her husband is a farmer who works a small parcel of land. They live in a village ten kilometers away from the town proper of Libertad, Antique, the last town of the northern part of the province, where job opportunities are very few. 

Visitacion sells vegetables to help support the family. Her two sons were not able to enroll in college after their secondary graduation. The family's income is not enough to send them to college. She is grateful to have ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) in their village so she can get capital to start a new business. She applied for this loan to buy native chickens to raise. She hopes that her membership will bring them good faith to improve their livelihood status.

loans.use: To buy native chickens to raise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sokneang

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokneang H., 26, and her husband, Mr. Titya Met, 28, who live on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, were married in 2000 and have three sons. One of their sons is in school and the other two are still too young.

Sokneang has been a silk weaver for two years; it is a skill she learned from her husband. They sell their finished product to the middleman who then takes it to sell in the market in Phnom Penh. She is requesting her first loan of $150 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Vuthy

texts.en:
Mr. Vuthy T., 38, and his wife, Mrs. Vanna Khorn, 38, live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1982 and have six children: five sons and one daughter. Two of their children work in a soft drink company, two children are in school and another one is still too young.

Vuthy and his wife have been farming for twenty-two years. They grow green beans and cantaloupes and other food crops on their farmland. Vuthy is asking for his second loan of $1,000 in order to build a restroom for use of the family. Another part of the loan will be used for his farming business.

loans.use: To build a restroom for his family and to use for farming

loans.name: Homid

texts.ru:
Эшонов Хомид 1981 года рождения имеет одного ребенка. Он закончил всего лишь 10 классов,в университете не учился.  
Сейчас он разводит дома скот, а в свободное время мастерит квартиры и помещения , куда приглашают на работу. Во дворе имеет 2 коровы. Также имеет около двух тон сена и других кормов для скота. он жалуется , что в прошлом году было холодно и скот было не чем кормить.  После холодной земли  на лугах мало было травы.   В этом году он благодарит бога за  то что на пастбищах  много травы и коровы и овцы приходят сытыми.
texts.en:
Homid E. was born in 1981 and has one child. He graduated from secondary school, but was not able to go to college. Now he breeds cattle at home, and in his spare time works as a handyman. In his yard he has two cows. In addition, he has nearly two tons of hay and other cattle feed. Unfortunately, last year it was cold and there was nothing to feed the cattle. Due to the cold ground, there was little grass in the meadows. However, this year he thanks God that there is a lot of grass in the pastures and the cows and sheep can eat their fill.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy K., 43, and her husband, Mr. Pov Thorn, 44, were married in 1988 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. The eldest son is a sewing machine repairer and the other two children are in school. The family lives along National Road Number One about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Chanthy has been a garment factory worker for ten years. Her husband has been a farmer for two years. He grows vegetables. Besides farming he is a chef as well - he cooks for wedding ceremonies.

Chanthy is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to build a concrete and brick room under her wooden house and to build a restroom for the use of her family.

loans.use: To build a concrete and brick room under her wooden house and to build a restroom for her family to use

loans.name: Vuthy

texts.en:
Mr. Vuthy L., 33, and his wife, Mrs. Sang Phan, 28, were married in 2000 and have three daughters. One of them attends school and the other two are still too young. Besides his wife and children, he also has his mother and one brother living with him. The family lives in a small village aL. National Road Number Two about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Vuthy has been an electrician and plumber for fifteen years; he works in his village and he sometimes works in the other provinces using his own motorbike. His wife has been selling Cambodian cakes for seven years. She sells them in Takmao market.

Vuthy’s motorbike has broken down so he is asking for a loan of $1,200 to purchase a new one.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike to drive to work

loans.name: Sa'ed

texts.en:
Sa’ed A. is a loving husband and father. In pursuit of a better quality of life and to obtain the necessary resources for his wife and his son, he decided to begin his own business. So he started to sell fruit and vegetables. This business is in a strategic location and is rapidly generating a very good income.

Sa’ed has applied for a loan of $1,200 to purchase greater volumes of fruit and vegetables.

He and his family greatly appreciate the trust and support that you offer them. Today is the time to help.

loans.use: To purchase greater volumes of fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy S., 35, and her husband, Mr. Yoeurn Khiev, 42, who live along National Road Number One, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 2006 and have no children. She also has her father living with her.

Chanthy and her husband have been growing rice for ten years. Besides growing rice they also sell vegetables. They buy them from the other villages for resale in the Phnom Penh market.

Chanthy is applying for a loan of $1,200 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides for growing rice.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides for growing rice

loans.name: Kimlun

texts.en:
Mrs. Kimlun S., 35, is single and lives on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. She has living with her, two brothers who attend school and one sister who is a silk weaver. Besides her brothers and sister she also has one aunt living with her.

Kimlun has been a silk weaver since she was fourteen years old. It is a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished product to the middleman who then takes it to sell at market in Phnom Penh.

Kimlun is asking for a loan of $250 to purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Kunthea

texts.en:
Mr. Kunthea H., 43, and his wife, Mrs. Phanith Bun, 43, who live along National Road Number One, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1989 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. Three of their children are in school and the other two are still too young.

Kunthea has been growing rice and cucumbers for fifteen years. His wife sells cucumbers which her husband has grown and she also buys some cucumbers from her villagers for resale at Plov Thmey market.

Kunthea is applying for his first loan of $500 to use for growing rice and cucumbers.

loans.use: To use for growing rice and cucumbers

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Yorn P., 50, is a widow with six children: three sons and three daughters. Three of her children are married and live outside the family home, two children are assisting their mother with farming and the other one is in school. The family lives along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Yorn has been a farmer for over thirty years; she grows papayas, tomatoes, corn and bananas. She hopes to support her children’s further education.

Yorn is requesting a loan of $500 to pay fees for growing papayas.

loans.use: To pay fees for growing papayas

loans.name: Duoc's Group

texts.en:
Được Nguyễn Thị was born in 1971. 010117050031. She lives with her husband and 2 daughters in Dai Bi village. She is a farmer and her husband is a builder. They have a monthly income of around VND 2,500,000 (about US $140). She is requesting VND 6,322,000 (about US $356) to have more capital to buy fish to resell in the market. She is the group leader.

Besides her there are 2 members in her group: 
Que H. T. was born in 1949, no. 010117050040, and is borrowing VND 4,142,000 over 12 months to buy goods to resell. 
Oanh N. T. K. was born in 1959, no. 010117050036, and is borrowing VND 5,014,000 over 12 months to buy chicken feed.

loans.use: to buy fish to resell in the market

loans.name: Isroil

texts.ru: Исроил Нурбеков 1980 года рождения, женат, имеет 4 детей. Он разводит коз белых и черных.  Его основной источник дохода , это продажа скота. В год 2 раза он стрижет коз и продает шерсть. Переработка шерсти дополнительный источник дохода, в основном белая пряжа идет реализацию. А также, продает молоко и молочные изделия. В Микроинвест обратился по совету отца. Получив кредит купил скот. Благодарен КИВА за поддержку.
texts.en:
Isroil N. was born in 1980. He is married and has four children. He breeds white and black goats, and his main source of income is the sale of livestock. Twice a year he shears the goats and sells the wool. Processing of the wool is an additional source of income, and the white yarn is sold. In addition, he sells milk and milk products. Isroil turned to MicroInvest for a loan on the advice of his father. With the loan he received, he purchased livestock. He is grateful to Kiva for the support.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business development

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Mrs. Sum M., 46, and her husband, Mr. Phally Sok, 46, live along the Tonle Basac River (a tributary of the nearby Mekong) about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1981 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. The eldest son is a driver for a company and two children are in school.

Sum and her husband have been growing and selling jasmine flowers for nine years. They also buy some jasmine from her village for resale at a market in Phnom Penh. She is asking for a loan of US $800 repair her motorbike and to purchase flowers on contract for resale.

loans.use: Motorbike repair and to purchase flowers for resale

loans.name: Mai's Group

texts.en:
Mai Nguyễn Thị was born in 1964. (No 010117050005). She lives with her daughter. Her daughter is studying at the university in Ha Noi city. She is a worker in a company. She wants to borrow VND 6,322,000 (about US$ 355) to buy some pigs. She has a monthly income of about VND 1,500,000.

Quyen N. T. was born in 1973. (No 010117050002). She lives with her husband and 3 children in Dai Bi village. She and her husband keep the car in the market. They have a monthly income of about VND 3,000,000. She is requesting VND 5,886,000 (about US $331) to have more capital to buy some trees.

loans.use: To buy some pigs

loans.name: Sokhoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Sokhoeun N., 25, and his wife, Mrs. Lalin Sor, 23, live on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2002 and have two young daughters.

Sokhoeun has been a mason for two years; he works in Phnom Penh. His wife stays at home to take care of their children. She used to be a garment factory worker. Sokhoeun is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase one generator for the family's use.

loans.use: To purchase a generator

loans.name: Sida

texts.en:
Mrs. Sida S., 49, and her husband, Mr. Doeun Dorn, 49, live along national road number one about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1982 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. Two of their children were married and live outside the family home and three daughters are garment factory workers.

Sida has been selling vegetables and pickles for ten years. She buys them from Sre Ampel market for resale at Koki market. Her husband has been a wooden house builder for fifteen years. Doeun doesn’t have enough construction materials for his business S. Sida is asking for her first loan of US $1,000 partly to purchase construction materials for her husband's business, and partly to buy vegetables for resale.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for her husband’s business and to buy vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Vun

texts.en:
Mrs. Vun H., 55, and her husband, Mr. Den Yem, 57, live on an Island in Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1970 and have three children: one son who is in grade 10 and two daughters who are silk weavers.

Vun use to be a silk weaver, but she stopped weaving and gave her looms to her daughters. They sell their finished products to a middleman who then sells them in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a farmer; besides farming he raises cows as well. Vun is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to add to her own money to purchase oxen for her husband to raise.

loans.use: To add in her own money to purchase oxen for husband to raise.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria C. is a 49 year old mother of six. Her husband, Eliobe, is a carpenter. This couple were previously employed in a shop where they made native plates and baskets. The baskets are made from “ipgid”, a wild vine that grows in the virgin forest of Libertad, Antique. Upon learning about ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), the couple has decided to apply for a loan to start their own business. Maria has applied for this loan to buy raw materials in bulk to continue making the plates and baskets. She wants to maintain her very good performance in the organization so that she can apply for a larger capital loan in the future. She plans to expand her business by establishing a shop and employing some of her neighbors in order to keep up with her orders. She plans to seek customers not only locally, but also abroad.

loans.use: To buy assorted raw materials in bulk for making native plates and baskets.

loans.name: Sieng

texts.en: Mrs. Sieng V., 51, has a job as a vegetable seller. She sells her vegetables to buyers at the market and she is earning around $3 per day. She has six children who are single and living with her. Four of them are employed. Two daughters are garment workers and two sons are blacksmiths. V. hopes to build her son's business using this loan to buy additional ferrous materials.

loans.use: To buy additional ferrous materials for her son

loans.name: Morn

texts.en:
Mrs. Morn M., 63, is widow with seven children: two sons and five daughters. Two of their children were married and live outside the family home and four other children are garment factory workers. Besides her children, she also has one young grandchild who is living with her. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number five about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Morn has been selling Cambodian cakes at her house for four years. She is requesting her first loan of US $300 to fill up the land at the back of her house.

loans.use: To fill up the land at the back of her house.

loans.name: Sam-At

texts.en:
Mr. Sam-at S., 27, has been married for one year. He lives with his mother in a small village off of National Road number Two about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sam-at used to drive a motor Remoque (a motor with a trailer at the back) taxi because he was ill; he decided to sell his motor Remoque to pay for medicine and hospital fees. But he now is better and he wants to purchase one motorbike to run a motor taxi business. That why he is requesting a loan of US $250 to add to his own money to make the purchase.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to use as a motor taxi

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a trailer to carry fruits and to buy fruits for resale.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Truyền năm nay 43 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2005.  Hiện nay hai vợ chồng chị Truyền đều đang làm nghề buôn bán cá. Do sống ở vùng biển Nghệ An nên công việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị có rất nhiều thuận lợi với nguồn hàng cung cấp cho thị trường người tiêu dùng ở địa phương rất ổn định.  Với mức thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng kinh tế gia đình chị Truyền đang ngày càng ổn định và phát triển hơn.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu tư  vốn cho công việc buôn bán cá của gia đình.
texts.en:
Ms. Nguyễn Thị Truyền is 43 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 2005. Today, she and her husband both sell fish for a living. Since they live in the waterfront town of Nghệ An, they have had success with their family business in being able to consistently meet the demands of the local community. With an income of 3,000,000 VND per month, Ms. Truyền's family's financial situation continues to improve each day. For the upcoming loan cycle, she hopes to borrow 20,000,000 VND to invest further into the family's fish marketing business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business - Selling Fish

loans.name: Bisoliha

texts.en:
J. Bisoliha has been an active and one of oldest clients of MicroInvest. She applied first to MicroInvest in 2002. She lives in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan and she trades in the local bazaar selling fruits and dry fruits. Bisoliha has been engaged in fruit selling for 6 years. She works closely with collective farmers so she has the opportunity to trade with lower prices than the bazaar prices.

Bisoliha applies to Kiva with the request of a business support loan of 1600 TJS for 6 months for to increase her area of trade. She thanks Kiva for its support of small business development.

loans.use: To increase her area of trade

loans.name: Orl

texts.en:
Mr. Orl A., 33, makes a living by buying and selling motorbikes. He normally purchases the motorbikes to paint them and resell them to gain income. Beside this, he is also a local construction foreman. He is married to Sroy, 34, a good housewife who cares for the children and cooks tasty meals for the family. The couple has two young children who are enrolled in the primary school.

To enlarge the business and to earn additional income, A. is applying for a loan to add to his existing capital. He will use the money to buy more motorcycles to resell to gain income and to buy a cow from a farmer to raise and sell its offspring.

loans.use: To buy more motorcycles to resell and a cow

loans.name: Samer

texts.en:
Samer S. is a single young man with big wishes of improvement; he started his beauty salon 4 years ago, offering his services as a hair stylist. Because of his love for this job and the good service he offers his clientele has multiplied and his business has grown.

In order to offer high quality services, Samer is requesting a US $1000 loan, which he’ll invest in the renovation of his salon and buy more marketing products and supplies. You can be part of Samer’s accomplishments and he is sincerely thankful for the help you are providing him.

loans.use: Salon renovation and purchase of products and supplies

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia T. is a 52 year old mother of four. Her husband, Lourdey, is a farmer. The family lives in the last town of Libertad in the northern part of Antique province, Philippines. This is a beautiful village where the mountains meet the sea. Lucia joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) so that she could apply for a loan to buy a pig. This, her first loan, will be used to buy the pig for fattening to augment their income. Lucia hopes to be able to raise more pigs in her backyard in the future so that she can supply meat to her town. She wants to save enough money for her sons and daughters to finish their college education and get good jobs.

loans.use: To buy one head of pig for fattening.

loans.name: Bazhan Group

texts.en: Bazhan S. A. is the group leader of the Bazhan group. There are four members in this group. Each member of the group has a business that will benefit from this loan. The money will be used to purchase materials for these local businesses. Bazhan’s loan will provide necessary materials for his book store. Shareifa wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. Gull Sherin will use the loan for his brother’s general store business. Maleha wants to take a loan for her cosmetics shop.
